P.title: Will SpaceX's Starship enable the commercialization of space travel by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, SpaceX has officially begun commercial operations of its Starship spacecraft for the purpose of space travel accessible to non-governmental, paying customers. Commercialization is defined as offering and conducting paid space travel services to individuals or private entities beyond governmental or scientific missions. The service must be operational, with at least one commercial flight completed. Confirmation must come from an official SpaceX announcement or credible media reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event of a partial service offering (e.g., limited to specific routes or types of customers), the question will resolve as Yes if the service is intended for broader public availability. Temporary or promotional one-off flights do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q_given_P.title: Given SpaceX's Starship enables the commercialization of space travel by 2025, will SpaceX establish a permanent human settlement on Mars before 2040?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2040, SpaceX has established a permanent human settlement on Mars. A "permanent human settlement" is defined as a self-sustaining habitat capable of supporting human life indefinitely without requiring constant resupply from Earth. The settlement must include living quarters, life support systems, and facilities for at least 10 people. The establishment of the settlement must be confirmed by SpaceX through an official announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The settlement must be operational, not in a trial phase. Temporary habitats or research stations do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will North Korea engage in a significant diplomatic negotiation with a Western country by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, North Korea has engaged in significant diplomatic negotiations with at least one Western country. Significant diplomatic negotiations are defined as official talks directly involving North Korean and Western country representatives, aimed at addressing major policy issues, security concerns, or normalization of relations. The negotiations must be officially acknowledged by both participating parties or confirmed through a joint statement. In the absence of official acknowledgment, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient for resolution. The term "Western country" refers to any country in North America, Western Europe, or Australasia. Preliminary talks, unofficial dialogues, or negotiations solely through intermediaries do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q_given_P.title: Given North Korea engages in significant diplomatic negotiations with a Western country by 2025, will it significantly reform its legal system by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, North Korea has implemented significant reforms in its legal system. Significant reforms are defined as changes that lead to increased transparency, the establishment of independent judiciary bodies, the introduction of laws that significantly enhance human rights protections, or the reduction of the government's direct control over legal proceedings. The reforms must be recognized and reported by at least three reputable international news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, Reuters) or international human rights organizations (Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch). In the absence of direct reports, official government announcements or documentation will be considered. The question will resolve as No if such reforms are not implemented or if they are reversed before the resolution date. In the case of ambiguous reforms, a consensus among the aforementioned sources will be required to determine the significance of the reforms.

P.title: Will a new AI-driven epidemiology tool predict the next global pandemic with over 90% accuracy before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a new AI-driven epidemiology tool is developed and successfully predicts the next global pandemic with over 90% accuracy. The prediction must be specific to the pathogen type (e.g., virus, bacteria), its origin, and the timeframe of outbreak. The tool's prediction accuracy must be verified by a consensus of at least three leading health organizations (e.g., WHO, CDC, ECDC) or by publication in at least three peer-reviewed scientific journals. The tool must be publicly acknowledged by these organizations or publications as having met the 90% accuracy threshold in its prediction. In the event of multiple tools meeting these criteria, the resolution will be based on the first tool to be publicly acknowledged as meeting the accuracy threshold. Predictions made retrospectively, after the pandemic has begun, do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on a new AI-driven epidemiology tool predicting the next global pandemic with over 90% accuracy before 2030, will the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines lead to a permanent change in workplace dynamics by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:

The prediction must be specific to the pathogen type (e.g., virus, bacteria), its origin, and the timeframe of outbreak. The tool must be publicly acknowledged by these organizations or publications as having met the 90% accuracy threshold in its prediction. In the event of multiple tools meeting these criteria, the resolution will be based on the first tool to be publicly acknowledged as meeting the accuracy threshold. Predictions made retrospectively, after the pandemic has begun, do not count towards this question's resolution.

Then, will the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines lead to a permanent change in workplace dynamics by 2030? This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a significant and permanent change in workplace dynamics directly attributable to the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines. Significant change is defined as:
- A permanent increase of at least 20% in the number of employees working remotely or in hybrid models compared to pre-pandemic levels (2019).
- The implementation of permanent flexible working hours by at least 50% of Fortune 500 companies.
- The establishment of permanent health and safety protocols in the workplace, including but not limited to vaccination requirements, that were not standard prior to the pandemic.

Changes must be documented by credible sources, including but not limited to surveys by major human resources consultancies (e.g., Deloitte, PwC), reports from reputable news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian), or official statements from companies. Temporary measures or changes solely due to government mandates that are lifted do not count towards this question's resolution.

Temporary measures or changes solely due to government mandates that are lifted do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a significant discovery in particle physics be made through computational methods by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant discovery in particle physics is made through computational methods. A "significant discovery" is defined as a discovery that leads to a substantial revision of the Standard Model of particle physics, or provides empirical evidence for phenomena not predicted by the Standard Model, such as supersymmetry, extra dimensions, or dark matter interactions.

The discovery must be confirmed through publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal of high impact (e.g., Nature, Science, Physical Review Letters) and must be recognized by a leading scientific organization in the field of particle physics (e.g., CERN, Fermilab, International Particle Physics Outreach Group).

Computational methods include, but are not limited to, simulations, data analysis algorithms, and machine learning techniques. The use of computational methods must be central to the discovery, not merely supplementary.

In the event of multiple discoveries, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets the above criteria.

In the absence of direct evidence linking the breakthrough to string theory, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The breakthrough must represent a substantial improvement over current capabilities and not merely an incremental advancement.

P.title: Will France implement a nationwide carbon-neutral initiative by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, France has officially implemented a nationwide initiative that is recognized as carbon-neutral. The initiative must encompass actions across multiple sectors, including but not limited to energy, transportation, industry, and agriculture, aimed at achieving a net-zero carbon footprint for the country.

The initiative must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient.

For the purpose of this question, "carbon-neutral" means that any carbon emissions produced by France are balanced by an equivalent amount of carbon sequestration or offsetting measures, within the same calendar year. The verification of carbon neutrality must be conducted by an independent, internationally recognized environmental organization.

In the event of partial implementation (e.g., limited to specific regions or sectors), the question will resolve as Yes only if there is a clear, government-confirmed plan for nationwide coverage by the end of 2030.

Q_given_P.title: Given France implements a nationwide carbon-neutral initiative by 2030, will significant advancements in climatology lead to a major shift in global climate policy by 2030?

A "significant advancement" in climatology is defined as a breakthrough in climate science that leads to a new understanding of climate systems, significantly improves climate models, or provides novel solutions to climate change. A "major shift" in global climate policy is defined as the adoption of new, substantial climate policies or amendments to existing policies by at least three of the following entities: the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the European Union, the United States, China, and India. These policies must represent a significant departure from current strategies and aim to substantially reduce greenhouse gas emissions or enhance climate resilience. P.title: Will Tesla's advancements in battery technology significantly reduce carbon emissions worldwide by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Tesla's advancements in battery technology have led to a significant reduction in global carbon emissions. A "significant reduction" is defined as a decrease of at least 10% in global carbon emissions from 2020 levels, attributable directly to the adoption of Tesla's battery technology in electric vehicles, energy storage systems, or other applications. The assessment of Tesla's impact on carbon emissions will be based on data and analysis from authoritative sources such as the International Energy Agency (IEA), the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), or equivalent. Reports from at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the reduction and Tesla's contribution to it will also be considered sufficient for resolution. In the absence of clear data linking Tesla's battery technology to a global emissions reduction, the question will resolve as No.

Further, this question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, the United Nations officially adopts a new global climate agreement aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions, promoting sustainable development, or enhancing international cooperation on climate change. P.title: Will the United States lead the world in quantum computing technology development by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the United States is recognized as the global leader in the development of quantum computing technology. Leadership will be determined based on the following criteria:

- Number of quantum computers developed that surpass the capabilities of existing classical computers in significant computational tasks (quantum supremacy).
- Volume and impact of peer-reviewed scientific publications originating from the United States that contribute to quantum computing technology.
- Investment in quantum computing research and development by both the public and private sectors in the United States, compared to other countries.

Global leadership must be recognized by at least two of the following authoritative sources: the International Quantum Computing Association, the IEEE Quantum Computing Task Force, or significant coverage in at least three major technology or science news outlets (e.g., Wired, MIT Technology Review, Nature).

In the event of a dispute over leadership, the consensus among these sources will be considered definitive.

P.title: Will the average global temperature increase by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels before 2050?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2050, the global average temperature is confirmed to have increased by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels (defined as the average global temperature from 1850-1900). The assessment must be based on the annual average global surface temperature data as reported by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) or another authoritative scientific body that is recognized by the scientific community. In the event that the IPCC or the designated authoritative body discontinues, merges, or is replaced, the most directly comparable successor organization will be used for the resolution. Should there be significant controversy or dispute within the scientific community regarding the accuracy or interpretation of the data, the question will resolve based on the consensus opinion of the scientific community as reflected in peer-reviewed scientific literature.

Q_given_P.title: Given a global temperature increase of more than 2 degrees Celsius before 2050, will a new infectious disease emerge with a global infection rate exceeding 1% before 2030?

The infection rate must be confirmed by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The global infection rate is defined as the percentage of the world's population confirmed to be infected by the disease, as reported by the WHO or CDC. In the absence of direct reports from these organizations, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) will be considered sufficient. In the event of conflicting reports, the average of the reported rates from these sources will be used to determine the resolution. This question does not consider the severity of the disease or the death rate, focusing solely on the infection rate.

If the first condition is not met, this question resolves as N/A.

P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur: (1) By December 31, 2030, a significant international climate change treaty is ratified. A "significant" treaty is defined as one that includes commitments from at least 75% of the world's nations and aims to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% from 1990 levels by 2050. The treaty must be ratified by the participating countries' governments or relevant governing bodies. Ratification is confirmed through official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The treaty must be new, not an amendment or extension of an existing treaty. In the event of multiple treaties, the question resolves as Yes if at least one meets these criteria. (2) By December 31, 2025, a major scientific breakthrough in renewable energy technologies is announced to have emerged from Iran. A "major scientific breakthrough" is defined as a discovery or development that significantly advances the field of renewable energy, such as a new method of energy generation, storage, or efficiency improvement that surpasses current leading technologies by at least 20% in efficiency or cost-effectiveness. The breakthrough must be recognized by the international scientific community, evidenced by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal of high impact or a major international scientific award. Reports from reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the breakthrough and its significance are also required. The breakthrough must be attributed to research conducted primarily in Iran, regardless of the nationality of the researchers.

P.title: Will DeepMind develop a breakthrough AI model for predicting pandemics before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, DeepMind has developed and publicly announced a breakthrough artificial intelligence model specifically designed for predicting pandemics. A "breakthrough" is defined as a significant advancement over existing models in terms of accuracy, speed, or predictive capabilities, as recognized by the scientific community or a leading health organization (e.g., WHO, CDC). The model must demonstrate its effectiveness through peer-reviewed research or a public demonstration of its predictive capabilities. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The model must be operational and available for use by health organizations or the public. In the event of a collaborative development with other entities, the question will resolve as Yes only if DeepMind's contribution is pivotal and acknowledged as such by the collaborating entities or in the official announcement.

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on DeepMind developing a breakthrough AI model for predicting pandemics before 2030, will a major infectious disease outbreak lead to the implementation of new global health policies by 2025?
Q_given_P.body:

A "breakthrough" is defined as a significant advancement over existing models in terms of accuracy, speed, or predictive capabilities, as recognized by the scientific community or a leading health organization (e.g., WHO, CDC). The model must be operational and available for use by health organizations or the public. In the event of a collaborative development with other entities, the question will resolve as Yes only if DeepMind's contribution is pivotal and acknowledged as such by the collaborating entities or in the official announcement.

This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major infectious disease outbreak has led to the implementation of new global health policies. A "major infectious disease outbreak" is defined as an event where a disease causes significant morbidity or mortality in at least three countries across different WHO regions, and is officially declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) by the World Health Organization (WHO).

New global health policies must be adopted by at least five member countries of the United Nations and aim to address the prevention, preparedness, or response to infectious diseases. These policies must be documented in official government publications or announcements. In the absence of such documentation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence.

In the event that multiple outbreaks occur, the question will resolve as Yes if any one of them meets the criteria above.

If the condition is not met, resolves N/A.

P.title: Will advancements in microbiology influence global health policies more than technology by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, advancements in microbiology have had a more significant influence on global health policies than technological advancements. Influence on global health policies is defined as the adoption of new or revised policies, guidelines, or recommendations by at least three of the following organizations: World Health Organization (WHO), Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), or similar national or international health bodies. The influence of microbiology advancements is measured by the direct citation of microbiological research or data in the formulation of these policies. Technological advancements include, but are not limited to, developments in medical devices, health information technologies, and biotechnology. The comparison between the influences of microbiology and technology will be assessed based on the number of policies influenced, the scope of the impact, and the depth of the changes implemented. In the event of ambiguity or lack of clear evidence, the question will resolve as No.

P.title: Will robotics achieve a major breakthrough in autonomous vehicle technology by 2025?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major breakthrough in autonomous vehicle technology is achieved, defined as:

- The development and successful public demonstration of an autonomous vehicle capable of navigating complex urban environments without human intervention, with a success rate of at least 95%.
- The breakthrough must be recognized by a leading industry body or consortium in the field of robotics or autonomous vehicles, such as the Association for Advancing Automation (A3) or the International Federation of Robotics (IFR).

The breakthrough must be documented in at least two reputable technology or science news outlets (e.g., Wired, TechCrunch, Science Daily) or in peer-reviewed scientific journals. 

In the event of multiple claims of breakthroughs, the resolution will be based on the first documented instance meeting the above criteria. 

Developments that only incrementally improve existing technologies without demonstrating a significant leap in capabilities will not be considered a major breakthrough for the purpose of this question.

Q_given_P.title: Given a major breakthrough in autonomous vehicle technology by 2025, will Amazon deploy an AI system capable of fully autonomous warehouse management by 2025?
Q_given_P.body:

- The development and successful public demonstration of an autonomous vehicle capable of navigating complex urban environments without human intervention, with a success rate of at least 95%.
- The breakthrough is recognized by a leading industry body or consortium in the field of robotics or autonomous vehicles, such as the Association for Advancing Automation (A3) or the International Federation of Robotics (IFR).
- The breakthrough is documented in at least two reputable technology or science news outlets (e.g., Wired, TechCrunch, Science Daily) or in peer-reviewed scientific journals. 

In the event of multiple claims of breakthroughs, the resolution is based on the first documented instance meeting the above criteria. 

Developments that only incrementally improve existing technologies without demonstrating a significant leap in capabilities are not considered a major breakthrough for the purpose of this question.

Then, will Amazon deploy an AI system capable of fully autonomous warehouse management by 2025? The system must be capable of operating without human intervention for tasks including but not limited to inventory management, order processing, packaging, and shipping. The deployment of such a system must be confirmed by an official Amazon announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The system must be operational, not in a trial phase. In the event of a partial deployment (e.g., limited to specific warehouses), the question resolves as Yes if the system is intended for nationwide or global expansion. Temporary deployments for specific events or the use of similar technology in private spaces do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will the US House of Representatives pass significant legislation to regulate artificial intelligence by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the US House of Representatives has passed legislation that significantly regulates artificial intelligence (AI) in any of the following areas: development, deployment, ethical use, privacy, security, or bias mitigation. 

Significant legislation is defined as a bill that introduces new regulations or substantially amends existing regulations on AI. The bill must be passed by the US House of Representatives and must not be solely symbolic; it must have practical implications for the regulation of AI. 

The passage of the legislation must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. 

In the event that multiple pieces of legislation are passed, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets the criteria outlined above.

P.title: Will a breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology be achieved by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology is achieved and publicly announced. A "breakthrough" is defined as achieving a net energy gain from a nuclear fusion reaction that is sustainable and reproducible in a controlled environment. The breakthrough must be recognized and confirmed by at least one of the following: the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the Department of Energy (DOE) of the United States, or a similar authoritative body in the field of nuclear energy. Additionally, the achievement must be documented in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or presented at a major scientific conference. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient. The question will resolve as No if these conditions are not met by the specified date.

Q_given_P.title: Given a breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology by 2030, will the United States become the world's largest producer of renewable energy by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: A breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology is achieved and publicly announced by December 31, 2030. A "breakthrough" is defined as achieving a net energy gain from a nuclear fusion reaction that is sustainable and reproducible in a controlled environment. The breakthrough must be recognized and confirmed by at least one of the following: the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the Department of Energy (DOE) of the United States, or a similar authoritative body in the field of nuclear energy. Additionally, the achievement must be documented in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or presented at a major scientific conference. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient.

Then, will the United States become the world's largest producer of renewable energy by December 31, 2030? This will resolve as Yes if the United States is officially recognized as the world's largest producer of renewable energy, measured by total megawatts (MW) of renewable energy capacity installed or by total renewable energy generated in a year. Renewable energy includes solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass energy sources. The assessment will be based on data and reports from authoritative sources such as the International Energy Agency (IEA), the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), or equivalent. In the event of discrepancies between sources, the source with the most comprehensive and recent data will be considered authoritative. The resolution will consider only operational capacity, excluding projects under construction or in planning stages. In case of a tie or near-tie (within a 1% margin), the question will resolve as No, requiring clear leadership in renewable energy production.

P.title: Will France experience a major social movement leading to significant policy changes by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, France has experienced a major social movement that leads to significant policy changes. A "major social movement" is defined as a widespread mobilization of people across multiple cities, recognized by major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Le Monde, France24) and involving at least 100,000 participants in total. "Significant policy changes" refer to legislative or executive actions that alter national policy in at least one of the following areas: labor laws, environmental regulations, social welfare, or civil rights. The changes must be directly attributable to the social movement and recognized as such by at least two of the aforementioned news organizations. In the event of multiple movements, the question resolves as Yes if any one of them meets these criteria. Temporary or symbolic measures do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a major technology company face a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government before 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a major technology company (defined as a company with a market capitalization exceeding $100 billion USD at the time of the investigation's announcement) faces a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government. A "landmark ethics investigation" is defined as an investigation that is publicly announced by a U.S. federal government agency, such as the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the Department of Justice (DOJ), or the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), and involves allegations of significant ethical breaches that could potentially lead to regulatory changes, substantial fines, or major shifts in company policy. The investigation must be new and not a continuation or expansion of previously known issues. Confirmation of such an investigation must come from official government releases or credible news reports from reputable sources such as The New York Times, The Washington Post, Reuters, or Bloomberg. In the event of ambiguous situations, the resolution will default to a No unless clear evidence is presented.

P.title: Will a major technology company face a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government before 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a major technology company (defined as a company with a market capitalization exceeding $100 billion USD at the time of the investigation's announcement) faces a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government. A "landmark ethics investigation" is defined as an investigation that is publicly announced by a U.S. federal government agency, such as the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the Department of Justice (DOJ), or the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), and involves allegations of significant ethical breaches that could potentially lead to regulatory changes, substantial fines, or major shifts in company policy. The investigation must be new and not a continuation or expansion of previously known issues. Confirmation of such an investigation must come from official government releases or credible news reports from reputable sources such as The New York Times, The Washington Post, Reuters, or Bloomberg. P.title: Will the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines lead to a permanent change in workplace dynamics by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a significant and permanent change in workplace dynamics directly attributable to the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines. Significant change is defined as:
- A permanent increase of at least 20% in the number of employees working remotely or in hybrid models compared to pre-pandemic levels (2019).
- The implementation of permanent flexible working hours by at least 50% of Fortune 500 companies.
- The establishment of permanent health and safety protocols in the workplace, including but not limited to vaccination requirements, that were not standard prior to the pandemic.

Changes must be documented by credible sources, including but not limited to surveys by major human resources consultancies (e.g., Deloitte, PwC), reports from reputable news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian), or official statements from companies. Temporary measures or changes solely due to government mandates that are lifted do not count towards this question's resolution.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) a major epidemic influence the outcome of a national election in any country before 2030 and (b) the United Kingdom launch a new national health initiative to combat future pandemics by 2025?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur: (a) Before January 1, 2030, a major epidemic significantly influences the outcome of a national election in any country. A "major epidemic" is defined as an outbreak of disease that results in significant morbidity or mortality, receives widespread national or international media coverage, and is officially declared an epidemic by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the national health authority of the country in question. The influence on the election outcome must be clearly attributable to the epidemic, such as through a significant shift in public opinion, voter turnout, or the implementation of election-related policies (e.g., mail-in voting, election postponement). The determination of significant influence will be based on analysis from at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or academic publications. In the event of multiple epidemics influencing elections in different countries, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first verified instance. (b) By December 31, 2025, the United Kingdom has officially launched a new national health initiative aimed at combating future pandemics. The initiative must be comprehensive, addressing at least prevention, detection, and response strategies for future pandemics. It must be officially announced by the UK government or a relevant health authority. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The initiative must be new, not an extension or rebranding of existing programs. In the event of a partial launch (e.g., limited to specific regions or aspects of pandemic preparedness), the question will resolve as Yes if the initiative is intended for nationwide application.

P.title: Will the United States become the world's largest producer of renewable energy by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the United States is officially recognized as the world's largest producer of renewable energy, measured by total megawatts (MW) of renewable energy capacity installed or by total renewable energy generated in a year. Renewable energy includes solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass energy sources. The assessment will be based on data and reports from authoritative sources such as the International Energy Agency (IEA), the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), or equivalent. In the event of discrepancies between sources, the source with the most comprehensive and recent data will be considered authoritative. The resolution will consider only operational capacity, excluding projects under construction or in planning stages. In case of a tie or near-tie (within a 1% margin), the question will resolve as No, requiring clear leadership in renewable energy production.

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on the United States becoming the world's largest producer of renewable energy by 2030, will there be a significant scientific discovery that influences US environmental policy by 2025?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the United States is officially recognized as the world's largest producer of renewable energy, measured by total megawatts (MW) of renewable energy capacity installed or by total renewable energy generated in a year. Renewable energy includes solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass energy sources. The assessment will be based on data and reports from authoritative sources such as the International Energy Agency (IEA), the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), or equivalent. In the event of discrepancies between sources, the source with the most comprehensive and recent data will be considered authoritative. The resolution will consider only operational capacity, excluding projects under construction or in planning stages. In case of a tie or near-tie (within a 1% margin), the question will resolve as No, requiring clear leadership in renewable energy production.

This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a significant scientific discovery is made that directly influences United States environmental policy. A "significant scientific discovery" is defined as a discovery that leads to the enactment of new legislation, significant amendment of existing legislation, or a major shift in policy direction at the federal level. The discovery must be related to environmental science and must be recognized as significant by the scientific community, as evidenced by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or endorsement by a major scientific organization. The influence on policy must be clearly attributable to the discovery, as confirmed by official government documentation or statements from relevant policymakers. In the absence of direct government confirmation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence of the discovery's impact on policy. Temporary measures or executive orders that do not lead to lasting policy change do not count towards this question's resolution.

Suppose the following is true: The United States becomes the world's largest producer of renewable energy by 2030. Then is it true that there will be a significant scientific discovery that influences US environmental policy by 2025?

P_and_Q.title: Will the United States become the world's largest producer of renewable energy by 2030 and will there be a significant scientific discovery that influences US environmental policy by 2025?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur: (1) By December 31, 2030, the United States is officially recognized as the world's largest producer of renewable energy, measured by total megawatts (MW) of renewable energy capacity installed or by total renewable energy generated in a year. Renewable energy includes solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass energy sources. The assessment will be based on data and reports from authoritative sources such as the International Energy Agency (IEA), the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), or equivalent. In the event of discrepancies between sources, the source with the most comprehensive and recent data will be considered authoritative. The resolution will consider only operational capacity, excluding projects under construction or in planning stages. In case of a tie or near-tie (within a 1% margin), the question will resolve as No, requiring clear leadership in renewable energy production. (2) By December 31, 2025, a significant scientific discovery is made that directly influences United States environmental policy. A "significant scientific discovery" is defined as a discovery that leads to the enactment of new legislation, significant amendment of existing legislation, or a major shift in policy direction at the federal level. The discovery must be related to environmental science and must be recognized as significant by the scientific community, as evidenced by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or endorsement by a major scientific organization. The influence on policy must be clearly attributable to the discovery, as confirmed by official government documentation or statements from relevant policymakers. In the absence of direct government confirmation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence of the discovery's impact on policy. Temporary measures or executive orders that do not lead to lasting policy change do not count towards this question's resolution.
